title: Consumer groups back mortgage broker pay review
text:
As well as dominating home lending, the big banks own or have a major stake in 40 per cent of mortgage brokers.
Customers stand to gain from an official review of commissions paid by banks to mortgage brokers and laws requiring banks to clearly disclose their ownership of broking and advice businesses, consumer groups say.
In its response to the financial system inquiry, the government this week said the Australian Securities and Investments Commission would investigate the remuneration of mortgage brokers, which wrote more than half of all new home loans.
It will also introduce laws requiring broking and financial advice firms that are owned by banks to clearly disclose this, amid concerns banks may use these businesses to distribute products, harming competition.
Both measures are responses to concerns about "vertical integration" in finance: where banks become more dominant in other industries that distribute their products, including broking or wealth management.
Advertisement The financial system inquiry said vertical integration had the potential to limit competition, and needed to be monitored.
In response, the broking industry defended commissions and growing bank ownership by saying the share of broker-written loans going to the major banks was drifting lower.
Consumer Action Law Centre chief executive Gerard Brody said the ASIC review of broker pay should provide data on the incentives for mortgage brokers and how this influenced behaviour.
However, he said the government's plan to beef up disclosure requirements in mortgage broking and advice would not address the potential for conflicts of interest created by vertical integration.
"I think there are some problems with just relying on disclosure and I think we need to understand the actual incentives and understand if they are driving misconduct," he said.
Mortgage brokers are typically paid an upfront commission of 0.65 per cent of the loan's value and a trailing commission of about 0.25 per cent a year over the loan's life.
Consumer group Choice also backed the ASIC investigation, citing a shadow-shopping exercise from this year, which, it said, uncovered flawed recommendations from mortgage brokers.
Mortgage and Finance Association of Australia chief executive Siobhan Hayden said the industry welcomed the ASIC review.
While about 80 per cent of home loans were with the big four banks, she said the share of broker-written loans with the big banks was lower, at 69.8 per cent this year.
"Even with the introduction of vertical ownership, the proportion of loans being put with major banks has actually declined," she said.
Major banks own or have a significant stake in about 40 per cent of mortgage broking businesses, industry figures show.
Several of the biggest broking firms are at least partly owned by banks: CBA-controlled Aussie Home Loans; Mortgage Choice, in which CBA has a 20 per cent stake; and National Australia Bank's aggregators, Choice Home Loans and FAST.
Smaller lenders have previously raised concerns about the high level of bank ownership in mortgage broking and financial advice, questioning whether it has constrained competition.
"We strongly support transparency about ownership and remuneration in the financial sector, whether it's major bank sub-brands, financial advisers or mortgage brokers," said Luke Lawler, head of public affairs at Customer Owned Banking Association.
"Consumers are entitled to know who they are dealing with and who is paying who."
As well as lifting disclosure, the government supported the inquiry's recommendation to rename "general advice". It currently refers to information that does not take into account a customer's entire situation.
